bibl.title: Letter from Louise Young Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, February 3, 1901

div1.p: Louise Kean writes that Jefferson Randolph Kean is in Washington, D.C. for his promotion exam. She mentions that Ames has contracted yellow fever and that she attended a memorial service for Queen Victoria.

div1.head: Letter from Louise Young Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, February 3, 1901
div1.p:
Your letter of the
29th reached me yesterday,
and I was so glad and so
relieved to have such good
news of George. Gertrude
and I had been comparing
notes ofover the telephone just
that morning, but neither
of us knew anything very
satisfactory or definite, so
I sent her word last night
by Gertrude Shaw about
your letter, and I am hop-
ing she will drive out to
see me this afternoon. I
do feel so sorry for you
and Molly, for all the
anxiety and trouble you
have had, and I wish I
had been nearer to help
you both. I wonder if
George will be strong e-
nough to come down with
Rannie. It would be
such a help to Molly if
they could come together.

Mama and I went in
to town yesterday, with
Capt. Slocum and Mrs.
McAlpin to attend the
memorial service for the
Queen. It was held in
the Commandancia del Marina, on the
Machina Wharf. It was very solemn and
impressive when we went in for the
house was all hung with black, and the
military band was playing a dirge, but
all the solemnity stopped with that. I
was so disgusted with the service. It con-
sisted of stupid addresses by four clergy-
men, who had been warned to avoid
all religion in their remarks, (!) and per-
fectly interminable music, opera I am sure,
very poorly sung by the troupe from
the Tacon. All the consuls were there in
their glittering uniforms, and Gen. Wood
and his staff in full dress. made us very proud of
our American men. But Mama, Mrs.
McA. and I stood the service for about
two hours, and then, as we were near
the door, we basely fled and left Capt.
Slocum, who was up in front with the
staff. It was such a theatrical hollow
performance, it did not seem possible
that it was in memory of dear, old
Queen Victoria. Why the British Consul did
not use his Prayer Book
I cannot imagine.

This morning Mrs. Mc
Alpin held a service in
the pavilion. It was
lovely, and her address
was really beautiful.
She had a service for the
men only Thursday night,
and there were four
hundred present! When
she is in Morristown
again, Mumsie, do meet
her, for she is perfectly
charming. So throughly
good, but so jolly and
an awfully good companion.
She has completely won
my heart. Gen. McAlpin
is expected next week
for a short visit. Capt.
Slocum says he is equally
charming, but quite a “bird.”
He is distressed that
Rannie is going to miss
Gen. McA. Of Of
course I have not had
time to hear from Rannie
yet, but I suppose he is
in Washington, and goes
up before the board to-
morrow. You will probably
hear from him before I
do. I hope the poor fellow
is not freezing to death
in what May Myrick
used to call the “cold and clammy north.”

Your beloved Bobs is getting bigger and
dearer every day. I don't see why the
little rascal does not get some teeth.
I wish he would, for I am getting quite
thin again, altho' I feel perfectly well.

I suppose you have realized that
Lawrence's regiment is ordered to
the Phillipines. And Dr. Reed goes
back to Washington next week. We will
miss him very much. Dr. Ames, the
“immune”, who took care of all the
yellow fever cases last year, is just
now recovering from an attack of yellow
fever! Nobody seems to have any very
definite opinion as to how he got it. I
went over to Camp Lazear the other day
and saw all the “loaded” mosquitoes.
It was very interesting, but rather creepy.

Tell Peg Bobs cap was a great deal too
small, but Mama made it big enough by
useing the piece that was turned back.
